name: Comprehensive Research Prompt for Digital Humanities Landscape

chat_messages.text:
Hi Claude. Here is a SWOT I wrote a few years ago on the topic of digital humanities. Please make me an exhaustive and thorough prompt for OpenAI's deep research. 

I would like you to instruct openAI's deep research in to do a thorough and exhaustive search of all open, high quality, and university sources around the multiple nodes of "Digital Humanities" in 2025. Specifically, to build an annotated bibliography by source to support an update of this SWOT, but not to do the SWOT. 

Give me a readback and functional decomposition of the thing. Do you need one of my prior prompts to openai?

content.text:

I would like you to instruct openAI's deep research in to do a thorough and exhaustive search of all open, high quality, and university sources around the multiple nodes of "Digital Humanities" in 2025. Specifically, to build an annotated bibliography by source to support an update of this SWOT, but not to do the SWOT. 

Give me a readback and functional decomposition of the thing. Do you need one of my prior prompts to openai?

attachments.extracted_content:
Digital Humanities SWOT analysis 

(Research experiment using perplexity.ai https://www.perplexity.ai/collections/DH-SWOT-prep-QRBYe_QaSo6LiEXObetJag?s=c) 

 

Objective: Understand and operationalise how universities across the world use the term “Digital Humanities” in terms of their centres, undergraduate and graduate offerings, labs, and research support services. 

 

Hot wash: DH is poorly operationalised. It may be any or all of: 

Corpus linguistics 

Digital Cultures 

“Big Data” 

GLAM preparation (plus magical technology) 

Websites and New Media 

KCL describes their department as all of the above: “The Department of Digital Humanities is a global leader in researching digital culture and society, and in exploring the use of advanced technology-related methods in humanities research.”1 notably offering “Digital Culture” as their only undergraduate degree.  

In contrast, if we look at ANU, their “School of Cybernetics” offers: “Cybernetics is the science of control and communication in complex systems such as computers, the human body, ecological systems, information systems, government and human cultures.  …  It was a way of thinking about how to build autonomous machines and ‘intelligent’ computing systems. It looked to processes in nature, and social systems, ... [and thus] generated ways of understanding how complex systems steer towards a goal, through interacting parts of a system that can sense, act, and respond to one another.” 2  

Whereas JLU (with whom we have a close relationship) says: “Digital Humanities (also e-Humanities and Computing in Humanities , i.e. “digital humanities”) is an interdisciplinary research area at the interface between the humanities and computer science. The subject of Digital Humanities involves the application of computer-based methods to work with digital resources such as text, audio and video. The aim of Digital Humanities is the differentiated and complex preparation and analysis of these resources, as well as ensuring their sustainable use.”3  

Whereas Western Sydney University says: “Digital Humanities is an emerging field of inter-disciplinary study. It involves the application of digital techniques and computational analysis to the sorts of research questions traditionally asked by scholars in the humanities disciplines.” But then shows their hand when they list the available jobs as “GLAM sector (galleries, libraries, archives or museums), … [and] The technology sector (e.g. social media and web design)”4 

A look at the DH2023 conference5 shows the same incoherence. Workflows, SPARQL queries, text analysis, cultural analysis, the semantic web, Natural Language Programming, web archives – while all very personally interesting, shows the fundamental “multidisciplinary’ (read: distracted) nature of the field.  

It’s digital humanities if it contains computers and “the humanities” (broadly conceived). The choice of technical and theoretical dial settings comes from the power plays and politics involved. JLU (Giessen) has an extreme emphasis on corpus linguistics due to the academic discipline of its President, Mukherjee (now at Cologne). ANU has cybernetics because of Professor Bell. KCL’s DH department was “... started as the 'Centre for Computing in the Humanities' in 1992.” And brought that “hypermedia” multidisciplinary big-tent focus forward. Even so, “... [the] Centre for Computing in the Humanities (CCH)) in 2015 split into the academic department, focussing on the teaching of digital culture, and King's Digital Lab, which operates the research and development activities formerly carried out by the Department/Centre”6 

Most universities have DH Centres for the multi-disciplinary people like me. They draw upon interested students and offer a haven for projects like Michagain State’s MATRIX center for digital humanities and social sciences. Even there, MATRIX focuses on cultural heritage and preservation – and builds software to do so, not least because of the influence of Ethan Watrall. 

The term is fundamentally incoherent. It has no particular relevance to employers, and judging from how it is sold to students as either “participate in a digital centre” or “digital cultures.” Many of the DH programs in Australia have been wound down over the last three years. Looking at the executive committee of the aaDH 7:  

Western Sydney: Masters discontinued in 2021 

Flinders: No DH. GLAM connection 

Monash: Corpus Linguistics, Big Data. DH major discontinued 2020 

Melb: DH unit discontinued 2021, GLAM focused 

ANU:  

Still offers a MA https://programsandcourses.anu.edu.au/2024/program/mdhpu 

Offers a minor https://programsandcourses.anu.edu.au/2024/minor/DIHU-MIN Mostly focused on digital culture and art due to the listed contact person. 

Extremely confusing 

Otago: Library support and a “hub” 

MQ: Shawn Ross.  

There are no commonalities, except for a decline in programs and scholarship in Australia since the pandemic. There is an insufficient core community of scholars here to support “training the next generation of academics.” And “eResearch” has fallen upon hard times across the sector. 

 

Strengths:  

Big Tent: Libraries, GIS, Digital Tools, Corpus Linguistics, “Big Data,” website publishing, digital automation, social media, digital cultures – all feature in some subset across all these centres and researchers. 

Provides an interdisciplinary space for deep collaboration between computing and the humanities, however construed. 

Enables new modes of research and more extensive research in Arts and Social Sciences. 

An established label to mean “computing bits” within arts and social sciences.  

Weaknesses: These are the internal factors that place the organization at a disadvantage relative to others. They could include areas where the organization is lacking or where improvements could be made. 

MQ has no infrastructure. According to a pre-covid eResearch survey, we have quite a distance to go before we achieve “average” eResearch support comparable to other universities. This is also the case for DH. 

The MQ FoA Strategic Plan asserts a “digital transformation” with relation to students and “and digitally enabled research in the strategic and everyday decision making of the Faculty of Arts.” -- this has not happened effectively. We do not have a digitally enabled research strategy.  

To improve this lack, we need to ensure that from a Workload perspective, building digital skills is an accepted use of Service time, that digitally enabled projects get “bonus points” in terms of promotion committee evaluations, and that we have enough infrastructure to allow for this encouragement. 

DH, as a sector, is “played out.” There has been a declining emphasis across Australia on “DH,” with minors, masters programs, and units being in decline. Bell’s work at ANU on cybernetics represents a pivot away from the Humanities. WSU has dropped their DH experiment, and Melbourne’s eResearch centre is also in decline. There is little to no evidence of DH or “digital culture” being relevant to students or employers. 

Digital skills are expected. Few folks know what that means beyond “competence with excel” or “Can use Adobe products.” There are significant missed opportunities here. 

We have no ability to teach these advanced digital skills within a humanities context. We have not the people, nor the time, nor the resources to support an initiative like this. If we were to change our priority, it would have to be at the expense of other opportunities. 

Our students are exhausted and from recent interactions, terrified of technology. There is a great anxiety around using Generative AI with the general feeling that (from discussions with multiple convenors) that it is just “too hard” (unfortunately a direct quote from a student) to use effectively.  

Our staff is exhausted and doesn’t have a good sense of where to begin, even if they had the time and resources to start. There is no sense that going down this route is an effective use of their limited time. 

Our HDR students are keen but lack supervision in this regard. We do not encourage the use of tools like LaTeX for thesis writing (as supervisors demand documents in Word), nor do we encourage supervisors to push their students in this direction. Again, it’s a resourcing and intention issue. 

Opportunities: These are external factors that the organization could exploit to its advantage. They could include market trends, changes in technology, policy changes, or shifts in consumer behaviour 

There are opportunities with Generative AI to have this be the spearhead of our focus. As Breen notes: “But the thing is: LLMs are deeply, inherently textual. And they are reliant on text in a way that is directly linked to the skills and methods that we emphasize in university humanities classes.”8 -- We have an opportunity to lead the university and the nation if we focus strongly on this digital opportunity. We have six months to start this pivot. 

DH is not a useful label for Generative AI, but there are people spruiking DH 2.0: https://www.unlv.edu/news/unlvtoday/digital-humanities-20-generative-ai-oct-24 There is an opportunity to follow Breen to argue for this label as part of our research. It could form a “Centre” (following most DH models) rather than a degree. 

There is massive demand for digitally literate students who can use prompts as part of their everyday work. “Prompt Engineering” utterly misses the point, but we can use this impluse to sneak in “telling stories about data” as a secondary objective – either as part of assessments, a unit on AI, or a named “DH” opportunity. 

 

Threats: These are external factors that could harm the organization. They could include competition, economic downturns, regulatory changes, or negative public perception 

We have no comms or guidance from the chancellery. While I helped write the guidance note for the use in Research – it's hard to tell what position they have on its use. (They do seem to be very excited to research about it, but it is harder to understand their position about its use.) 

No one in FoA “owns” DH/Generative AI – and is empowered to make decisions and policy across all of its facets. 

For Generative AI: 

There may be copyright or IP implications. There are certainly terms of service 	implications. 

Any meaningful use will have significant infrastructure costs. 

Any meaningful use will have extremely significant training implications. As well as additional time implications for assessment redesign. 

For DH: 

No reliable academic community in Australia – makes it hard to recruit academics 

We are at the wrong part of the cycle in terms of Australian support for this discipline 

Poorly operationalised and even more poorly understood – hard to sell as a desirable skill in this form. Few universities have demonstrated success with a DH degree (undergraduate or postgraduate.) 

 

Analysis:  

“Moral reforms and deteriorations are moved by large forces, and they are mostly caused by reactions from the habits of a preceding period. Backwards and forwards swings the great pendulum, and its alternations are not determined by a few distinguished folk clinging to the end of it. – Sir Charles Petrie, THE VICTORIANS.” (From Neal Stephenon, The Diamond Age) 

The pendulum has swung away from Digital Humanities 1.0 as it was concieved in the last two decades. While there are established and uncontroversial uses for Geographic Information Systems, Digital Cultures, Web Development, Corpus Linguistics, and “doing humanities with technology” -- the big tent approach supporting “digitally enabled scholarship”9 has ebbed after COVID. Universities across Australia have deemphasised or pivoted their Digitally Enabled Research/Digital Humanities support into specialised centres or approaches. ANU has Cybernetics (control systems, organisations, and societies – not merely robots) with a DH major run by an Art Historian. Their degree offering requires students to take digital culture, a light dusting of technology, and then a random set of Arts, Design, Computing, and Media units. This major maps quite closely to the one from King’s College London10. This ”Digital Culture” major is also offered by USyd11 , Queensland12, Newcastle13, and University of the Sunshine Coast14. Reading between the lines, these seem to advertise: ”how to be an online influencer.” GLAM, the more entailed technologies, corpus linguistics, and GIS have no mention in this “social media influencer’s degree.” We do not need to offer one of these.  

There are researchers exploring corpus linguistics here, at USyd15, and across Australia – but no extraordinary undergraduate emphasis on the topic. To a first approximation, much of the oxygen in the room has been consumed by ”Data Science” -- emphasising statistics and computer science over communications and effective comprehension. Most universities have GIS units, but few are part of the Arts and Humanities faculties. Internationally, DH usually takes the form of a research centre, operationalised according to the parent disciplines of the founders of the centre. I.e. Michagan State’s MATRIX center focuses on digital cultural preservation due to Watrall’s influence. Giessen (JLU) hosts the Text Encoding Initiative due to Mukherjee.  

The label “Digital Humanities” is worthless to undergraduates and of little value as a department label. The pendulum is at the extreme of its arc – though Generative AI and Breen’s “textual approach” to understanding these systems16 suggests that the pendulum may swing back the other way. The grave danger of Generative AI, in terms of employability, is Borgmann’s ”Efficiency for efficiency’s sake.”17 There are, suddenly, opportunities for ”Generative AI” degrees and units – those degrees should be in the Arts as the tools from arts: historiography, critical readings, and the very act of encoding expertise in a prompt are fundamentally textual and activities that history and philosophy may already contribute to. Digital techniques will be most useful and most opposed when they are embedded into assessment. They will be useful because many of our students will need to engage with digital tools – sources of data, analysis techniques, query techniques, prompt techniques (as of February) -- and will need to be able to examine them and tell stories. Not necessarily in the statistical sense, but the patterns of application and critical comprehension will be invariant for many jobs using the skills from our disciplines. 

However, these digital skills are antithetical to the self-narratives/mindset of many of our students and many of our faculty. Their narrative can be that they don’t see themselves as technical, that they don’t like or “get” programming.  

With the advent of Generative AI, these narratives of opposition may be subverted. While “knowing something about something” 18 is still necessary – knowledge of the technique’s existence and mechanisms of application is the minimum, rather than knowledge of how to use excel properly, or even to (heavens forbid) program. Thus, if we are to embrace the opportunities of digital humanities this decade, much of that hope lies with Generative AI. Though I still maintain that our geography department should offer GIS units.  

Our students must be able to ask questions of data and tell stories about the results, using the techniques and contexts of their disciplines. These questions should require transformation and analysis, not mere regurgitation. We must assume that effective Generative AI use is a prerequisite for graduation. We do not want to make “Digital Cultures” -- how to be an influencer – degrees.

chat_messages.text:
The user has shared a SWOT analysis they wrote on Digital Humanities and wants me to create a comprehensive prompt for OpenAI's deep research feature. They want this prompt to instruct Deep Research to gather thorough and exhaustive information about Digital Humanities in 2025 from various high-quality sources, particularly to support an update to their SWOT analysis.

Let me first analyze the content of the SWOT analysis to understand what's already covered and what needs updating:

Key points from the SWOT analysis:
1. Digital Humanities (DH) is poorly operationalized and can encompass multiple areas:
   - Corpus linguistics
   - Digital Cultures
   - "Big Data"
   - GLAM (Galleries, Libraries, Archives, Museums) preparation
   - Websites and New Media

2. Different institutions conceptualize DH differently:
   - King's College London (KCL): Broad approach including digital culture
   - Australian National University (ANU): Cybernetics approach
   - Justus Liebig University (JLU): Interdisciplinary research at the interface of humanities and computer science
   - Western Sydney University: Application of digital techniques to humanities questions

3. Strengths identified:
   - "Big Tent" approach allowing diverse applications
   - Provides interdisciplinary space for collaboration
   - Enables new research modes in Arts and Social Sciences
   - Established label for computing within arts and social sciences

4. Weaknesses identified:
   - MQ (Macquarie University?) lacks infrastructure
   - Lack of a digitally enabled research strategy
   - Declining emphasis on DH across Australia
   - Limited ability to teach advanced digital skills
   - Student and staff exhaustion/anxiety regarding technology

5. Opportunities identified:
   - Generative AI as a potential spearhead
   - Possibility of "DH 2.0" centered around AI
   - Demand for digitally literate students who can use prompts effectively

6. Threats identified:
   - Lack of communication or guidance from leadership
   - Unclear ownership of DH/Generative AI initiatives
   - Copyright/IP implications for AI
   - Infrastructure and training costs
   - Weak academic community in Australia for DH

Based on this analysis, I'll craft a prompt for OpenAI's Deep Research that addresses:
- Current state of Digital Humanities in 2025
- How different institutions globally are defining and implementing DH
- Trends in DH education and research programs
- The relationship between DH and generative AI
- Infrastructure and resources needed for effective DH programs
- Job market relevance for DH skills
- Best practices and successful models

The user wants an exhaustive and thorough prompt that will result in an annotated bibliography organized by source, not a completed SWOT analysis.

Now I'll craft this prompt with a functional decomposition to ensure comprehensive coverage.

# Prompt for OpenAI Deep Research: Digital Humanities in 2025

I've analyzed your SWOT document and crafted a comprehensive prompt for OpenAI's Deep Research. This will help gather the latest information to update your analysis with current developments in Digital Humanities.

## Primary Research Directive

Conduct a thorough and exhaustive search of all academic, institutional, and high-quality sources on Digital Humanities (DH) as of 2025. Create an annotated bibliography organized by source type to support an update of a SWOT analysis. Do not create the SWOT itself, but provide comprehensive source material that would enable such an update.

## Functional Decomposition of Research Areas

### 1. Conceptual Evolution of Digital Humanities
- How is "Digital Humanities" defined and operationalized across different institutions globally in 2025?
- Identify significant shifts in how DH has been conceptualized since 2020-2023
- Document how leading DH centers and departments frame their mission and scope
- Analyze whether the field has become more coherent or remains fragmented in its definition

### 2. Current Academic Landscape
- Catalog and describe active DH centers, departments, and labs at major universities worldwide
- Document undergraduate and graduate programs specifically focused on DH
- Identify trends in program creation, continuation, or discontinuation since 2020
- Compare curriculum structures and focus areas across different institutions

### 3. Relationship with Generative AI
- Research how DH has integrated or responded to generative AI technologies
- Document any emergence of "DH 2.0" frameworks incorporating AI
- Analyze how DH centers are researching, teaching, or utilizing generative AI
- Identify scholarly work examining the intersection of DH methodologies and generative AI

### 4. Infrastructure and Resource Models
- Identify successful models for DH infrastructure support at universities
- Document funding structures for sustainable DH initiatives
- Research technical requirements and platforms commonly used in current DH practice
- Compare resource allocation strategies across different institutional contexts

### 5. Employment and Skills Relevance
- Research current job market demand for DH-related skills
- Identify which specific DH competencies are valued by employers
- Document career outcomes for DH program graduates
- Analyze how industry perceptions of DH qualifications have evolved

### 6. Pedagogical Approaches
- Document innovative teaching methods in DH education
- Research assessment strategies that effectively incorporate digital tools
- Identify successful approaches to teaching technical skills to humanities students
- Compare student engagement and outcomes across different pedagogical models

### 7. Regional Developments
- Provide detailed analysis of the state of DH in Australia in 2025
- Compare with developments in North America, Europe, and Asia
- Identify regions experiencing growth vs. decline in DH initiatives
- Document international collaborations and knowledge exchanges

### 8. Future Trajectories
- Identify emerging technologies or methodologies being incorporated into DH
- Document scholarly predictions about the future evolution of the field
- Research strategic planning documents from major DH centers
- Analyze funding trends and priorities from major grant organizations

## Source Requirements

1. **Academic Publications**: 
   - Peer-reviewed journal articles from 2023-2025
   - Conference proceedings from major DH conferences (DH2023-2025)
   - Published books and edited collections on DH topics

2. **Institutional Sources**:
   - University websites, particularly DH centers and departments
   - Strategic plans and mission statements
   - Program descriptions and curriculum documentation
   - Annual reports from DH initiatives

3. **Professional Organizations**:
   - Publications and reports from ADHO, aaDH, and similar organizations
   - Job postings and career guidance materials
   - Professional development resources

4. **Industry Perspectives**:
   - Reports on skills demand from relevant industries
   - Case studies of DH applications in non-academic contexts
   - Partnership initiatives between universities and external organizations

5. **Government and Funding Bodies**:
   - Policy documents related to digital research and education
   - Grant priorities and funded project descriptions
   - National strategies regarding digital skills and humanities research

## Annotation Requirements

For each source, provide:
1. Complete citation in Chicago style
2. Brief summary of key findings or arguments (100-150 words)
3. Explicit relevance to SWOT categories (which strength, weakness, opportunity, or threat does this inform?)
4. Assessment of the source's reliability and potential limitations
5. Cross-references to other sources that confirm, challenge, or extend its findings

## Output Format

Organize the annotated bibliography by source type and then chronologically within each type. Include:
1. Executive summary highlighting the most significant findings (500-750 words)
2. Thematic clusters that emerged across multiple sources
3. Identification of knowledge gaps where further research is needed
4. Full annotated bibliography as described above
5. Index of institutions and their current DH initiatives

Does this approach encompass everything you need for your research? I can adjust any section to better align with your specific goals for updating the SWOT analysis.

content.text:
# Prompt for OpenAI Deep Research: Digital Humanities in 2025

I've analyzed your SWOT document and crafted a comprehensive prompt for OpenAI's Deep Research. This will help gather the latest information to update your analysis with current developments in Digital Humanities.

## Primary Research Directive

Conduct a thorough and exhaustive search of all academic, institutional, and high-quality sources on Digital Humanities (DH) as of 2025. Create an annotated bibliography organized by source type to support an update of a SWOT analysis. Do not create the SWOT itself, but provide comprehensive source material that would enable such an update.

## Functional Decomposition of Research Areas

### 1. Conceptual Evolution of Digital Humanities
- How is "Digital Humanities" defined and operationalized across different institutions globally in 2025?
- Identify significant shifts in how DH has been conceptualized since 2020-2023
- Document how leading DH centers and departments frame their mission and scope
- Analyze whether the field has become more coherent or remains fragmented in its definition

### 2. Current Academic Landscape
- Catalog and describe active DH centers, departments, and labs at major universities worldwide
- Document undergraduate and graduate programs specifically focused on DH
- Identify trends in program creation, continuation, or discontinuation since 2020
- Compare curriculum structures and focus areas across different institutions

### 3. Relationship with Generative AI
- Research how DH has integrated or responded to generative AI technologies
- Document any emergence of "DH 2.0" frameworks incorporating AI
- Analyze how DH centers are researching, teaching, or utilizing generative AI
- Identify scholarly work examining the intersection of DH methodologies and generative AI

### 4. Infrastructure and Resource Models
- Identify successful models for DH infrastructure support at universities
- Document funding structures for sustainable DH initiatives
- Research technical requirements and platforms commonly used in current DH practice
- Compare resource allocation strategies across different institutional contexts

### 5. Employment and Skills Relevance
- Research current job market demand for DH-related skills
- Identify which specific DH competencies are valued by employers
- Document career outcomes for DH program graduates
- Analyze how industry perceptions of DH qualifications have evolved

### 6. Pedagogical Approaches
- Document innovative teaching methods in DH education
- Research assessment strategies that effectively incorporate digital tools
- Identify successful approaches to teaching technical skills to humanities students
- Compare student engagement and outcomes across different pedagogical models

### 7. Regional Developments
- Provide detailed analysis of the state of DH in Australia in 2025
- Compare with developments in North America, Europe, and Asia
- Identify regions experiencing growth vs. decline in DH initiatives
- Document international collaborations and knowledge exchanges

### 8. Future Trajectories
- Identify emerging technologies or methodologies being incorporated into DH
- Document scholarly predictions about the future evolution of the field
- Research strategic planning documents from major DH centers
- Analyze funding trends and priorities from major grant organizations

## Source Requirements

1. **Academic Publications**: 
   - Peer-reviewed journal articles from 2023-2025
   - Conference proceedings from major DH conferences (DH2023-2025)
   - Published books and edited collections on DH topics

2. **Institutional Sources**:
   - University websites, particularly DH centers and departments
   - Strategic plans and mission statements
   - Program descriptions and curriculum documentation
   - Annual reports from DH initiatives

3. **Professional Organizations**:
   - Publications and reports from ADHO, aaDH, and similar organizations
   - Job postings and career guidance materials
   - Professional development resources

4. **Industry Perspectives**:
   - Reports on skills demand from relevant industries
   - Case studies of DH applications in non-academic contexts
   - Partnership initiatives between universities and external organizations

5. **Government and Funding Bodies**:
   - Policy documents related to digital research and education
   - Grant priorities and funded project descriptions
   - National strategies regarding digital skills and humanities research

## Annotation Requirements

For each source, provide:
1. Complete citation in Chicago style
2. Brief summary of key findings or arguments (100-150 words)
3. Explicit relevance to SWOT categories (which strength, weakness, opportunity, or threat does this inform?)
4. Assessment of the source's reliability and potential limitations
5. Cross-references to other sources that confirm, challenge, or extend its findings

## Output Format

Organize the annotated bibliography by source type and then chronologically within each type. Include:
1. Executive summary highlighting the most significant findings (500-750 words)
2. Thematic clusters that emerged across multiple sources
3. Identification of knowledge gaps where further research is needed
4. Full annotated bibliography as described above
5. Index of institutions and their current DH initiatives

Does this approach encompass everything you need for your research? I can adjust any section to better align with your specific goals for updating the SWOT analysis.
